race.name: Old Fashioned Gravel
race.tagline: Old Fashioned Gravel. 55 miles of gravel through Hokah.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Minnesota countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Minnesota event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Old Fashioned Gravel is a local event in Minnesota‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Minnesota countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Minnesota gravel race. Worth it for Minnesota/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Minnesota‚Äîyes, it's good value. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Minnesota races: Almanzo, Dirty Benjamin.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Hokah has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Hokah has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: Camping available in the pasture (riders could sleep in cars on-site, helpful due to high hotel prices)

non_negotiables.why: Minnesota rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Ian Breitlow, who has "done so many grassroots events in the Midwest," calls this "#1 for quality and hospitality" citing "hot coffee and pastries in the morning" and "super clean, not-porta potty bathrooms." Eric Cleveland noted "Maps were a bit wonky" and Carolyn Franzone got lost on the shake-out ride due to cue sheet errors.

length.explanation: 55 miles sits in that awkward middle distance where it's too short to be epic and too long to be casual. Four route options from 20-100 miles show they're trying to please everyone, which usually means pleasing no one particularly well. At least you can pick your poison. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: All routes start with "one mile of paved climb" before reaching gravel on the ridge, then descend the same paved section to finish. Kevin Huang summarized it as "Really mfn hard, really hilly" while Mark Lee noted the 40-mile had "great versatile terrain." The Driftless region delivers rolling hills, farms, and wooded descents. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 2500 feet over 55 miles averages to manageable suffering in Driftless region terrain. That's enough climbing to respect but not enough to break you, which fits their 'welcoming to novices' positioning. The paved climb start suggests at least one ascent, but this isn't the Rockies. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Uriah Matznick suffered a mechanical DNF at mile 40 of the 100-mile course, highlighting the self-supported nature where riders must "bring some sort of tire plug, inner tube, and Co2." The race warns "There will not be any mechanical support on the road, you are responsible for arranging a ride if you have issues." More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Southeast Minnesota's Driftless region sits at typical elevations of 800-1400 feet with no altitude training considerations. The paved climb to reach gravel on the ridge represents standard Midwest topography rather than any meaningful elevation challenge. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Leslie Johnson enjoyed "a true gravel experience highlighting MN rolling farmland, barns and bluff views" while Jeanne Fricke called it "one of the prettiest rides I've ever done." The Driftless terrain offers "spectacular views" with "wide open to wooded descents" and minimal pavement once riders reach the ridge system.

prestige.explanation: Ryan Greene, who "raced all over this year everything from Midsouth to Montana to Steamboat," noted "the only thing lacking was some organization and that big finish line feel" compared to established events. The race caps at 300 riders and launched in 2024, building grassroots reputation rather than national recognition.

race_quality.explanation: Colin Timm praised the "perfect blend of casual community riding and competitive racing" while Keith Rust would "give it a 10" if the scale went higher than 5. Ryan Greene ranked it among his "fav races of the year" despite noting minor organizational gaps typical of a second-year event finding its footing.

experience.explanation: The farm venue provides a "cool old structure with a rustic feel" barn as event center with post-ride "food, drink, and hangs with new friends." Erin Sullivan appreciated being able to "sleep in my car in the pasture" due to high hotel costs, while Phil Solberg had a "great experience" for his first gravel ride.

community.explanation: Race Director Paul Reardon emphasizes inclusivity: "if you want to come challenge yourself, or just go for a ride with other rad people, make new friends, eat, drink, and laugh, that's what it is all about!" Entry fees support local causes and the event partners with Hokah businesses for food and hydration.

field_depth.explanation: The 100-mile field shows modest competitive depth with winners around 4:44 and mid-pack finishing 2-3 hours later. Brian Werner's enthusiastic but generic review ("the venue was great, the route was great, the vendors were great") reflects a friendly participation-focused field rather than serious racing depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Four distance options, professional timing, food, drinks, and supporting local causes for an undisclosed but presumably reasonable entry fee delivers solid bang for buck. You're getting a organized event experience without the premium pricing of established races. Sometimes being nobody's first choice makes you everybody's good deal.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Hokah represents modest Midwest travel costs with car camping available in the farm pasture as Erin Sullivan utilized. Local business partnerships for food and lodging in what organizers call a "super cool little town" keep costs reasonable compared to destination race weekend gouging. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

2024.conditions: - Historical weather incidents (mud years, heat, wind): Unavailable; event founded in 2024, limited history
key_takeaways: Historical weather incidents (mud years, heat, wind): Unavailable; event founded in 2024, limited history
Race history (founded year, founder if known): New event launched in 2024; no founder named

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Old Fashioned Gravel gravel race Hokah

videos.title: Preview: First Paved Climb at 2025 USAC Gravel Nationals
videos.description: This is the first paved climb for the 2025 USAC Gravel Nationals, up Ridgeview Road. The climb starts about eight miles in to the route, just southwest of Hokah. The climb itself is just over a mile in distance, and ~350 feet in elevation change. The gravel begins at the top of the climb, as you hit the township line. Video here is from Sept 13, 2025 at the Old Fashioned Gravel event; there had been some light sprinkles just that morning, so the asphalt is damp. https://ridewithgps.com/routes/51956892?highlight=460-553
videos.curation_reason: Detailed course preview of specific climb section filmed during the Old Fashioned Gravel event with terrain and elevation details.

videos.title: Cycling Lefthand Canyon to Ward in Boulder, Colorado with Pro Triathlete Justin 'BIGMETZ' Metzler
videos.description:
Left Hand Canyon to Ward is a Bucket List Bike Ride and a Top US Climb. Watch this entire beautiful ride from a cyclist perspective as we ride along Lefthand Creek to the town of Ward. This ~17 mile ride will take you from ~5500 elevation to about 9000 elevation with an average gradient of 4%. 

Don't expect to be cruising this ride at 20mph has most Pro-Triathletes riding the "Wall" at 13-15mph. If you're a beginner aim for 5-8mph up the wall. This ride is challenging but beautiful and peaceful too.   

I would 10/10 recommend this ride for your next Cycling Vacation.

‚ú®  And if you like this video, consider subscribing to Justin Metzler using this Link! ‚§µÔ∏è
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCmuPpeDBniCq7s74-dUl_6w?sub_confirmation=1

********************
üé¨ Welcome to the Channel of Justin Metzler! üö¥üèª
Justin is a 27 year-old Ironman and 70.3 professional triathlete from the USA. Despite being one of the youngest on the circuit, Justin has deep triathlon experience doing his first race at the age of 13 in 2009. Metzler progressed through the ranks and quickly established himself as one of the premier half distance racers in the United States ‚úÖ
üëâüèº  Metzler wasted no time making a name for himself with a breakout 2014 season earning him the USA Triathlon rookie of the year. He continued to hone his craft, racing around the globe in search of experience and development. In the process he gathered 30+ top-5 finishes.

Justin is known for his consistency and passion on and off the race course. Triathlon is not only a profession for Metzler, it is a way of life that he has been enthusiastically pursuing for over a decade üíØ

üëâüèº  Metzler is part of the new wave of athletes coming to the sport from a pure triathlon background. His even development in swim, bike and run allows him to have a well rounded approach to racing and training. Having been first out of the water, first off the bike and having had the fastest run split, Justin has the tools and ambition to be world class in all three disciplines.

So, if you want to follow Justin‚Äôs journey subscribe, hit the bell button and enjoy! üõé

********************
From pure beginners to podium athletes! Justin‚Äôs Coaching üíØ

‚û°Ô∏è  Helping other athletes achieve their goals in sport has always been a big part of what I want to do. Coming from a place of passion and excitement, I aim to pair my formal education (Human Physiology) with over 10 years of real world triathlon experience to help athletes reach their dreams. 

In 2018 I teamed up with master coach Julie Dibens working under her JD Crew banner. With Julie and her two other coaches, Katie Kyme and Caitlin Snow, we help all different types of athletes from pure beginners to podium athletes at the Ironman World Championship. 

‚û°Ô∏è  If interested in our coaching services, reach out to me directly or to Julie via her website juliedibenscoaching.com

videos.title: That water is screaming
videos.description: This is what you hike in the entire time, wet socks and shoes for four days and freezing to the point of uncontrollable shivering! I had a hiking buddy Payo from Sweden for the first bit, but he turned around and gave up. I wanted to too, but I couldn't, God had other plans.............When God tells you to go, I suggest you listen.

videos.title: Top 4 Critical RWD Driving Mistakes You're Probably Making (Here‚Äôs Why + How to Fix Them)
videos.description:
Many people think that pressing the gas pedal too hard in low gears is the only danger of spinning a rear-wheel drive car. But to be honest? That's only ONE part of the truth! Discover in this video the top 4 rear-wheel drive (RWD) mistakes that even seasoned drivers sometimes make and learn how to correct them for a safer, more enjoyable driving experience. 

Whether you're new to RWD vehicles or looking to refine your driving techniques, this video is packed with expert insights and practical advice. We delve into the reasons behind these common errors and offer step-by-step guidance on how to fix them. Perfect for enthusiasts and everyday drivers alike, this guide will not only enhance your driving skills but also increase your confidence on the road. 

The videos were used in accordance with the "fair use" principles. Take a look at all the videos and channels here:

BMW e36 320i street drift fail
Nicklas Rossing

but I want to mention an essential

and low gears in a
curve I think I don't need to explain

points model where the tire only has 100

for steering and 100 points for
acceleration at the same same time the

this technique has another Advantage if
you slowly press the gas the weight of
the vehicle can shift to the back
allowing the tires to build more grip
the idea with the string also works for
braking the more you steer the more you

practice this process with low speed and
little braking pressure on any curve in
everyday life it really helps to build
up this
habit let's summarize this in four
golden rules one be careful when you let

RPM two shift into a lower gear before

more you break the less you can steer or

videos.title: Don‚Äôt Buy the Wrong ASICS! Full Review: Novablast 5, Gel-Cumulus 27, Gel-Nimbus 27
videos.description:
Which ASICS shoe is right for you? I compare the Novablast 5, Gel-Cumulus 27, and Gel-Nimbus 27 so you don‚Äôt waste money on the wrong one.

üìà Subscribe for more honest running reviews and training tips!

üîπ Running Plans for Every Level ‚Äì Find yours: https://stay-satisfied.com/pages/plans
üîπ Apply for Coaching ‚Äì Work with me 1-on-1: https://linktr.ee/runnerkarolineolsen

More Videos You‚Äôll Enjoy:
‚ù§Ô∏èMy Story: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5L8eZuMGRMU0sbyI8MvWPH7NWhKslD86
‚ù§Ô∏èMy Comeback: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5L8eZuMGRMWdGbkHWxust7VSpAyz0_t7
‚ù§Ô∏èFollow Along Workouts for Runners: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5L8eZuMGRMWdl0_gGUftjjBquIoCsNKh
videos.transcript:
Which AS6 are actually worth it? I've
tried all three, the Cumulus, Nova
Blast, and Nimbus. And here's what you
need to know. If you've never tried AS6,
expect a smooth, supportive ride with
secure heel fit and longlasting comfort.
It's different from brands like Nike or
Hoka because it's more structured, more
stable, and made to go the distance. The
Nimbus 27 is built for max comfort, so
super soft, plush, and protective. It's
perfect for long or recovery runs. And
if you're all about feeling good, this
is honestly your cloud ride. And I have
the black gray color. The Cumulus 27 is
your reliable everyday trainer. It's
balanced, smooth, and versatile. It's
great for easy runs, even errands, or
anything in between. Now, the Nova Blast
5. This one's light, bouncy, and has a
great energy return. It's great for
daily training, long runs, and even
tempo sessions. I recommend it for
runners who want a fun, energetic ride
that can still handle volume. A quick
heads up, these aren't carbon plated
race shoes, but I will say that the Nova
Blus 5 is light and responsive enough to
race a 5K, 10K, or even a half. If you
want one shoe for training and race day,
and I have the grayish
purple/coral color, if you want pure
softness and comfort, then go for the
Nimbus 27 for your easy runs or long
runs. If you want an everyday trainer
with a traditional feel, then go for the
Cumulus 27. If you want bounce and a
fast feel in a traditional trainer, then
